content.text: Without calculation, identify the fastest car and the slowest car
Complete the table
Calculate the speed of car \(\mathbf{B}\)
A student determines the speed of three cars on a straight road
The student measured the time for the cars to travel \(50 \text{m}\)
The table shows the measurements
Estimate the time, in minutes, for car \(\mathbf{C}\) to travel \(5000 \text{m}\)
estimated time =   .........  minutes
Explain why your answer in (b)(i) may not be the same as the actual time taken for the car to travel \(5000 \text{m}\)
Describe how the scientist can measure the volume of the object, using the method of displacement
The mass of the metal object is \(347\mathrm{g}\) and its volume is \(18\mathrm{cm}^3\)
Calculate the density of the metal
Fig. 2.1 shows a metal object discovered by a scientist using a metal detector
The scientist wants to know the type of metal from which the object is made. She needs to find the density of the metal
The weight of the box is 2250 N
Calculate the mass of the box
Calculate the moment of his force about the pivot. State the unit
The moment in (b)(i) is not sufficient to lift the lid. Describe how the man can increase the moment, using the same force
A man wants to lift the lid of the box. He puts a strong metal bar between the box and the lid. He applies a force to the bar as shown in Fig. 3.2
Fig. 3.1 shows a large box with a heavy lid
As the rubber band is pulled back, the work done is transferred into ............................ potential energy
When the student releases the rubber band, the ball moves forward horizontally. Stored
potential energy is transferred into ................................ energy
As the ball travels through the air there is friction with air molecules. This causes some of
the ball's .......................... energy to be transferred into ............................ energy
When the student releases the rubber band, the ball moves towards the target
Complete the following sentences about energy transfers during this process. Use words from the box. You may use each word once, more than once or not at all
The ball does not reach the target, as shown in Fig. 4.2
Describe how the student can increase the energy of the ball, using the same catapult
A catapult consists of a rubber band attached to a handle. A student uses the catapult to fire a ball towards a target. Fig. 4.1 shows the catapult just before the student releases the rubber band
State and explain the type of tyre that is suitable for travelling over soft ground
The temperature of the air in a tyre increases. This affects the motion of the air molecules in the tyre
Describe and explain the changes
A vehicle may have tyres of type **A** or type **B**, as shown in Fig. 5.1
Which of these metals is often used for the liquid in thermometers?
Tick the correct box
magnesium
mercury
silver
The thermometer is placed inside a freezer containing ice
Suggest the temperature of the ice. Draw an arrow on Fig. 6.1
A thermometer is calibrated using two fixed points. State the temperatures of the two fixed points
lower fixed point = ............................ \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
upper fixed point = ............................ \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
The sentences are about thermal processes
Complete each sentence. Use words from the box. Each word may be used once, more than once or not at all
A dull black surface is a good
Copper is used to make pans because it is a good thermal
In fluids, thermal energy is transferred mainly by
Thermal energy reaches Earth from the Sun by means of
Fig. 6.1 shows a liquid-in-glass thermometer
On Fig. 7.1, indicate the wavelength of the wave. Label the distance \(W.\)
Determine the amplitude of the wave
amplitude =   .........  \(cm\)
The ball reaches its maximum height 40 times in 60 seconds. Calculate the frequency of the wave
frequency =   .........  \(Hz\)
Explain how the motion of the ball shows that the water wave is transverse
State another example of a transverse wave
Fig. 7.1 shows a floating plastic ball attached by a long rope to a weight on the bottom of a lake. A water wave on the surface of the lake causes the ball to move vertically up and down
On Fig. 8.1, complete the ray diagram to show how the lens focuses the light
Which distance on Fig. 8.1 is a focal length of the lens? Tick \((\checkmark)\) one box
A ray of light travels through a semicircular glass block, as shown in Fig. 8.2
State the term given to the angle of incidence labelled z
Fig. 8.3 shows another ray of light travelling in the semicircular glass block
Fig 8.1 shows two parallel rays of light that pass through a thin converging lens. The diagram is incomplete. There is a principal focus at \(\mathrm{f}_{1}\) and at \(\mathrm{f}_{2}\)
A man sees the hammer hit the post and a short time later hears the sound of the post being hit. Explain the delay in hearing the sound
The hammer is \(320 \text{m}\) from a large building as shown in Fig. 9.2
The man hears the hammer hit the post and then hears an echo. Explain why he hears the echo
The speed of sound in air is \(320 \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the time difference between the man hearing the first sound and the time at which he hears the echo
time difference =   .........
Suggest how the sound of the echo is different from the first sound
A machine pushes a metal post into the ground using a hammer, as shown in Fig. 9.1. The hammer makes a loud noise when it hits the post
A man stands \(160 \text{m}\) from the hammer
On Fig. 10.1 carefully draw two magnetic field lines above the centre line XY and two magnetic field lines below XY.
Indicate the direction of the magnetic field lines. Use an arrow. Mark one field line above XY and one field line below XY.
State the name of a piece of equipment that can be used to determine the direction of the magnetic field
The student shows the pattern of the magnetic field lines around the magnet
Describe how the student can use a bar magnet to test whether a metal rod is a magnet
A student places a bar magnet onto a sheet of paper, as shown in Fig. 10.1
A teacher checks the circuit and identifies three errors
Using the components given in Fig. 11.1, carefully draw the correct circuit diagram in the space below
The student uses the correct circuit. The student finds that the current is 0.3A when the potential difference across the wire is 2.7V
Calculate the resistance of the wire
resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
for a wire that is longer, but of the same thickness,
for a wire that is thicker, but of the same length
The student tests two other pieces of wire made of the same metal. He compares each resistance value with that of the first wire
State how the resistance compares with the first wire
A student wants to find the resistance of a wire. He connects the circuit shown in Fig. 11.1
State the name of the electromagnetic radiation emitted by some nuclei when they decay
Describe the composition and the penetrating ability of an \(\alpha\) -particle
composition
penetrating ability
Americium-241 is a radioactive isotope. It has a half-life of 400 years
A sample contains americium-241. Calculate the percentage of americium-241 that remains in the sample after 800 years have passed
percentage remaining =   .........  %
This question is about radioactive materials
